datafield.subfield: Louise Talma was an American composer, pianist, and educator. She was a student of Nadia Boulanger and a long-time resident of Fontainebleau and the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, New Hampshire. The music materials in the collection consist chiefly of holograph manuscript scores, sketches, tone rows, and photo-reproduced manuscripts bearing annotations in the composer's hand. The remaining materials are not processed at this time and consist of correspondence, photographs, business papers, and other materials related to her career.

titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2011

did.head: Collection Summary
did.langmaterial: Material in English, French, German, and Italian
did.abstract: Louise Talma was an American composer, pianist, and educator. She was a student of Nadia Boulanger and a long-time resident of Fontainebleau and the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, New Hampshire. The music materials in the collection consist chiefly of holograph manuscript scores, sketches, tone rows, and photo-reproduced manuscripts bearing annotations in the composer's hand. The remaining materials are not processed at this time and consist of correspondence, photographs, business papers, and other materials related to her career.

note.label: Note
note.p: Only the music materials are available for research at this time.

The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Bequest, Louise Talma, 1996. Additional materials were received from Louis Martin in 1997.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The music materials from the Louise Talma Papers were processed by Lina Terjesen, Kelly Cornett, and Christopher Hartten in February-April 2011. The finding aid was coded for EAD by Christopher Hartten in 2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings from the Louise Talma Papers have been transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Talma's holograph score for Cantata: All the Days of My Life, commissioned by the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress, is cataloged under ML 30.3c.T345 no. 1. For more information, see catalog record: http://lccn.loc.gov/84756595. The Edward and Marian MacDowell Collection and the Charles Seeger Collection contain correspondence to and from Talma.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The Louise Talma Papers are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Louise Talma Papers are currently being processed. Only the music materials are available at this time. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Louise Talma Papers, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, Arcachon, France
Began piano lessons
Moved with mother, Cécile Talma, to New York
Studied at the Institute of Musical Art, New York City
Taught theory and ear training at the Manhattan School of Music
Studied piano with Isidore Philipp at the Fontainebleau School of Music
Studied composition with Nadia Boulanger at the Fontainebleau School of Music
Teacher and assistant professor of music, Hunter College, New York City
Bachelor of Music, New York University
Awarded Joseph Bearns Prize for Composition
Master of Arts, Columbia University
Became first American to teach at Fontainebleau

eventgrp.event: First visit to the MacDowell Colony, Peterborough, New Hampshire
Performance of Four-Handed Fun with composer and life-long friend Lukas Foss

chronitem.event: Composed Toccata for Orchestra
Awarded successive Guggenheim Fellowships
Periodically studied or taught solfege, analysis, and harmony at Fontainebleau
Composed The Divine Flame
Awarded Fulbright Fellowship
Composed The Alcestiad
The Alcestiad becomes the first American opera to be performed at a major European opera house
All the Days of My Life commissioned by the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress
Became first woman elected to the National Institute of Arts and Letters
Composed Infanta Marina
Died at the Yaddo Artist Colony, Saratoga Springs, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Music materials from the Louise Talma Papers span the period 1875 to 1996, with the majority dating from 1928 to 1994. These consist chiefly of holograph manuscript scores, sketches, tone rows, and photo-reproduced manuscripts bearing annotations in the composer's hand. Many works are accompanied by errata, correspondence, programs, notes, and other items of interest. Talma's tendency to date sketches and manuscripts at different stages in her creative process is useful for tracing her compositional shift from neoclassicism to serialism and atonality. Her final work, Spacings (1994), was completed at Yaddo only two years before her death and marked the end of a nearly seventy-year career as a composer. Notable manuscripts in the collection include holograph scores for the opera The Alcestiad (1958) and the oratorio The Divine Flame (1946-1948), Four-Handed Fun (1943), Piano Sonata no. 1 (1943), and her award-winning Toccata for Orchestra (1944).

Talma also possessed a variety of music manuscipts from other composers, many of whom she met while at Fontainebleau, the MacDowell Colony, and Yaddo. Her close relationship with Lukas Foss is evident by the significant quantities of inscribed holograph scores that the renowned composer gave to Talma throughout the 1940s and 1950s. These include his Concerto for Piano and Orchestra no. 2 (1949-1951), Fantasy Rondo (1944-1945), The Jumping Frog of Calaveras County (1949), Psalms (1956), and Song of Songs (1946). The collection also contains holograph scores by Leonard Bernstein, Norman Dello Joio, and Irving Fine, as well as an 1875 printed edition of Karl Goldmark's Symphony no. 1 inscribed by Marian MacDowell to Talma.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Louise Talma Papers
arrangement.p: The Louise Talma Papers are organized in one series:
